is a town in the northern part of the

. The town was built on the back of the aviation industry and was the site of the first powered flight in Britain, made by Samuel Cody in 1904. Today, the aerospace and technology industries survive and aviation heritage is evident all around the town. Farnborough is perhaps best known as the home of the biennial

, which has been running for over 60 years. 

The town is currently undergoing rapid development including a radical rebuilding of the shopping centre to include new shops, bars, restaurants, cinema and hotels.

Much of the land previously used by the military is now been redeveloped to build new apartments, hotels and bars.
Farnborough is well served by airports. For travellers coming directly to Farnborough, the closest airports are:

Take the tube (Victoria line to Oxford Circus, then Bakerloo line to Waterloo is the best way) to London Waterloo station. Trains depart for Farnborough Main 4 times an hour Monday-Saturday and every hour on Sundays.

Farnborough also has its own private airport,  It should be noted that there are no scheduled commercial flights to Farnborough but rather it is the base of operation of two of the largest private jet hire companies in the UK.

Farnborough is served by four railway stations:

value: Farnborough North and North Camp railway stations (same line) for

Farnborough is served by the M3 motorway which runs from London to Southampton. It is about an hour's drive from central London. The best junctions to use for Farnborough are junction 4 or 4a and then follow the signs.

Farnborough is a small town and so it is very easy and quick to get around on foot or by car. There are a number of local bus services which serve the town from Kingsmead bus station in the town centre, the main ones being:

content=Built by the French Empress Eugénie, this is the burial place of Napoleon III, Emperor of the French, his aforementioned wife, Eugénie de Montijo, and their son, Louis Napoléon Eugène. The abbey is also home to a small group of Benedictine monks, who open their gates to visitors most Saturday afternoons. Visitors receive a guided tour by one of the monks, which takes them to the chapel and the Imperial Crypt. There is an opportunity to buy historical and religious memorabilia, as well as food produced on site by the abbey's small farm.
http://www.stpetersfarnborough.org.uk/ St Peter's Old Parish Church
is believed to house the remains of many of the Earls of Anglesey, and is a pretty church in its own right.

content=Offers activities such as new indoor and outdoor climbing facilities, an archery range, rifle shooting, orienteering, caving, and with the benefit of being located next to the Basingstoke Canal, watersports such as kayaking, canoeing and raft-building. There is permanent indoor accommodation and an extensive area for camping.
name=The Farnborough Air Sciences Trust (F.A.S.T) Museum

content=In Trenchard House on Farnborough Road. A little-known local gem featuring many documents and models relating to aviation. Of particular note are the static aircraft outside, the to-scale replica of Samuel Cody's first aeroplane (which made the first powered flight in the United Kingdom at Farnborough in 1908) and an interactive fighter pilot simulation in a real cockpit. The museum is staffed by friendly and knowledgeable volunteers who are occasionally a little too keen to talk to you in depth about engineering and aerodynamics! Open every Saturday and Sunday, admission is free but a small donation or some money spent in the souvenir shop would be warmly welcomed.
is held every two years, in summer.  Public days are the last weekend only.  Exhibits cover civilian & military hardware both static and as an aerial display.

The town centre is reasonably well-equipped with high street chains and supermarkets, but it has a smaller range of shops than might be expected for a town its size. For a larger range of shops, the nearby town of Camberley is more promising, and slightly further afield
are the leading regional shopping centres. In the south of Farnborough, the suburb of North Camp

has a varied selection of independent specialist shops, including but not limited to bakeries, butchers, delicatessens, ethnic grocery stores, cakemakers, bookstores, interior design and sports and outdoor equipment.
